Executive Summary
Savanna Street and Trahon/Big Creek Wastewater Treatment Facilities
EPA I.D. 1000 000 7329 (Savanna)
EPA I.D. 1000 000 7285 (Trahon/Big Creek)

Facility Descriptions and Regulated Substances Handled

The City of Jackson, Mississippi owns three (3) Wastewater Treatment Facilities that use and store chlorine and sulfur dioxide chemicals:

A?    0.75 MGD Hydro Clear Sand Filter Process
A?    4.5 MGD Oxidation Ditch Process
A?    46.0 MGD Single Stage Nitrification Process

The above processes are operated and maintained by Severn Trent Environmental Services, Incorporated. With the exception of the Hydro Clear Sand Filter Process, the remaining processes use and store chlorine and sulfur dioxide that exceed the threshold specified in the Risk Management Plan rule. 

    Savanna Street and Trahon Big Creek WWTFA?s

The Savanna Street WWTF treats wastewater from Hinds, Madison, and Rankin 
Counties, which is chlorinated and dechlorinated in the gaseous form prior to discharge into the Pearl River. The site has 32,000 pounds of chlorine stored at any given time. The process has four (4) headers that are capable of feeding 8,000 pounds/header. The cylinders are on a standby/on-line basis to insure that the chlorination process is continuous. Chlorine is drawn from the 1-ton containers.

The Trahon/Big Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant treats wastewater from the South Jackson and Byram areas. The facility discharges treated wastewater into Big Creek, thence to the Pearl River. The site has 4,000 pounds of chlorine stored at any given time. Sulfur Dioxide is stored in twelve (12) 150# cylinders. 
Process Safety Information 
Savanna Street has Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) for all chemical substances and equipment specification sheets for every single piece of equipment, each piece of equipment's upper and lower limits, approved operating procedures, training manuals and process description write-ups, maximum intended inventory, fire water drawin

gs, management of change, safety and environmental procedure involved in the chlorination system whose Process Flow & Instrumentation Diagrams (P & IDs) are up to date.  The technical information for the chlorination system is stored in the facility's operating manual.  The Process & Instrumentation drawing for the chlorination system is currently up to date
                                    
    Process Hazard Analysis 
Savanna Street has employed the Hazard Review Checklist, What-if questions, and Hazop procedures for the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). The PHA for the chlorination system discusses the hazards of the process, the engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazard as well as the consequences of failure of administrative and engineering controls. This PHA was conducted May 18, 2009 and May 28, 2009.
There are provisions in its organizational infrastructure to accommodate a PHA Team which consist of an Area Manager, Safety Administrator, Two (2) Technicians, one (1) Lift Station Supervisor and a Chief Operator, who are responsible for conducting, updating and re-validating the analysis.

In addition to provisions for the PHA Team, there are written policies and procedures describing the team's purpose, goals and objectives, as well as how it functions. 

There is documentation that shows not only has Savanna Street developed, but has actually implemented a PHA procedure that; promptly addresses the PHA Team's findings and recommendations are resolved in a timely manner, and that the resolution is documented; document what actions are to be taken; make certain that actions are taken as soon as possible; a written schedule of when these are to be completed; a system for communicating these actions to operating, maintenance and other personnel affected by these actions. 
Operations and Maintenance Training 
A general and unit specific Operations Training Program has been established at the Savanna Street facility in general and the Chlorination Systems in particular.

Operations personnel are tested both based on their knowledge of various pertinent topics as well as by their performance (hands-on). 
Initial training emphasizes safety and health hazards as well as safe work practices. Operators can only work the unit themselves after being fully trained. Based upon Savanna Street RMP documentation, there are provisions for refresher training for each operator every year.                     
Preventive Maintenance/Mechanical Integrity 
Savanna Street has resident stationary and rotating equipment maintenance and instrument mechanics. Process instrumentation is monitored and calibrated regularly. Meetings between Operations, Maintenance and Process Engineering personnel on maintenance issues, among other things, are conducted on a regular basis. Operating and maintenance personnel, among other things, are assessing the results of the non-destructive testing of the piping and equipment to determine what and where chlorination system equipment repairs, replacement and/or upgrades, due to corrosion, may be warranted. 
Since the chlorine supplier owns the ton cylinders of chlorine, the pressure vessel inspections are performed by them and documented.           
Management of Change 
The written procedures (Checklist and Instructions) for the Management of Change (MOC) Risk Management Plan (RMP) were updated on June 5, 2009. There are provisions for informing employees who will be affected by the change as well as provisions for training them on the new items prior to the start-up of the process, or affected part of the process. The Area Manager must approve any changes before the changes begin.
Compliance Audits 
The last audit was conducted by the Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality conducted an audit on April 3, 2007. 
Incident Investigation 
Although there is a process for Incident and Accident investigations, there have not been any accidents or incidents at the Savanna Street Facility that warranted an investigation during the revie

w period.
                
Employee Participation 
Employee Participation includes the Monthly Health and Safety Training Meetings. Meetings for all employees are held at the Savanna plant. The Process Hazard analysis (PHA) and Incident Investigation Reporting are part of the Monthly Health and Safety Training Meetings 


Hot Works Permits 
Issuances of hot work permits are part of the standard operating procedures at Savanna Street. Before any hot work is done, a permit must be obtained. There are hot work permit files kept at the facility for hot work operations that have been completed.


    Worst Case Release Scenarios                                         
The EPA mandates that the Worst Case Release Scenario has a release of the entire contents of the largest single container of each regulated substance during a 10 minute period with a wind speed of 1.5 meters/second., and a F atmosphere stability class. Distances for releases were developed using tables listed in the EPAA?s A?RMP Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.A? For a one (1) ton release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas, the distance to the Toxic Endpoint is 1.3 miles urban (Savanna-Population of 3,031)) and 3.0 miles rural (Trahon- Population of 4,186)

    Alternate Release Scenarios (Savanna and Trahon)

As recommended by the RMP Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants,A? a wind speed of three (3) meters/second and D atmosphere stability class were used. Gas was assumed to be released through a one (1) inch diameter break in the supply piping. The release scenarios for chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage assumed the release of 135 pounds, producing a distance of to the end point of 0.1 miles.

    General Accident Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps

The Savanna facility is manned 24 hours/day, including holidays by two (2) operators. The operators make daily inspections at least twice/shift. The systems have gas monitors or leak detectors that activates flashing lights. Pursuant the Emergency Response program, two (2) trained o

perators are required to respond to all leaks. If the leak is too severe, said operators are required to notify the Senior Admin Assistant to activate the plant wide audible alarms. All personnel will be required to vacate the premises. The plant entrance gate has a warning light and a sign that forbids anyone from entering the plant when said light is flashing. The Trahon facility is manned eight (8) hours/day and 4 hours/weekend day. The facility has leak detectors as well. However, the facility is equipped with a telemetry system that alarms at the Savanna plant.  

    Five-Year Accident History
    
    None for both facilities during the last five (5) years













Executive Summary
Savanna Street WWTP

    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

    The City of Jackson and its wastewater treatment operator, Severn Trent Environmental Services, Inc. are dedicated to the proper use of chemicals in a manner which is safe to the environment and people.  Chemical storage areas and process equipment are regularly inspected, repaired and upgraded to prevent accidental releases.  Should an accidental release occur, response activities will be coordinated through the Hinds County Emergency Operations Center and the Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality.  On-site plant personnel are trained to make repairs to contain small accidental releases.

Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

The Savanna Street Wastewater Treatment Plant treats sewage from most of Jackson, East Rankin County and West Madison County, discharging the treated water into the Pearl River.  The plant uses chlorine gas to disinfect the wastewater.  Sulfur dioxide gas is used to dechlorinate the wastewater prior to being discharged into the river.  The chlorine gas is stored in 32 one-ton cylinders.  The sulfur dioxide gas is stored in 8 one-ton cylinders.  At a given time, 8 of the cylinders are connected on a single header.

Worst-Case Release Scenarios

EPA mand

ates that the Worst Case Release Scenario have a release of the entire contents of a largest single container of each regulated substance during a 10-minute period with a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second and F atmospheric stability class.  Distances for releases were developed using tables listed in EPAA?s A?RMP Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants.A?  For a 1-ton release of chlorine of sulfur dioxide gas, the distance to the A?Toxic EndpointA? is 1.3 miles, affecting approximately 3.035 residents and nearby schools, major commercial areas, and the recreational area along the Pearl River.

Alternative Release Scenarios

As recommended by the A?RMP Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants,A? a wind speed of 3.0 meters per second and D atmospheric stability class were used.  Gas was assumed to be released through a 1A? diameter break in the supply piping.  The release scenarios for chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage assumed the release of 135 pounds, producing a distance to the A?Toxic EndpointA? of 0.1 miles, affecting no residents.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps

The plant is manned 24 hours each day including holidays with at least two operators. These operators inspect the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems at least twice each shift.  The chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems have area gas monitors which trigger flashing lights and audible alarms.  Maintenance personnel are immediately called in to stop small releases.  The operation and maintenance of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide equipment are performed in accordance with manufacturerA?s instructions.  Operations and maintenance personnel receive regular training the use and maintenance of the equipment through monthly safety meetings, seminars provided by the equipment manufacturers and formal classes provided through the Mississippi Water and Pollution Control OperatorsA? Association and others.




Five-Year Accident History

During the last five years, the plant

has not had any releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide which resulted in death, injury, evacuations, property damage or environmental damage.

Emergency Response Program

The savanna Street Wastewater Treatment Plant has developed an emergency response program.  Once it is determined that a situation is larger than what can be handled by Plant personnel, the situation will be reported to the 911 emergency dispatcher, who will then contact the appropriate emergency response agency, such as the City Fire Department, City Police Department and Hinds County Emergency Operations Center (EOC).  Through discussions in monthly Safety Meetings, through formal training conducted by the Mississippi Water and Pollution Control OperatorsA? Association and others and through annual emergency drills, plant operations and maintenance personnel will be properly trained in limited emergency response.  As the situation warrants, the public will be notified through the respective Public Affairs personnel at the Police, Fire and Public Works Departments and the EOC.  In the event telephone contact is not possible, emergency dispatch will be conducted using the City-wide radio system.

Planned Changes to improve Safety

A UV system was installed to reduce the amount of chlorine used and the system has been re-engineered by the installation of vacuum regulators on all one-ton cylinders.  24 hours plant security has been added, and the Business Management system inplemented to assess risks.
